DBLP:conf/icwsm/GuoBRL22.title: Emotion Regulation and Dynamics of Moral Concerns During the Early COVID-19 Pandemic
DBLP:conf/icwsm/GuoBRL22.author:
Siyi Guo and
Keith Burghardt and
Ashwin Rao and
Kristina Lerman
DBLP:conf/icwsm/GuoBRL22.paperMotivationText: The COVID-19 pandemic has upended daily life around the globe, posing a threat to public health. Intuitively, we expect that surging cases and deaths would lead to fear, distress and other negative emotions.
DBLP:conf/icwsm/GuoBRL22.paperContributionText: Ssing state-of-the-art methods to measure sentiment, emotions, and moral concerns in social media messages posted in the early stage of the pandemic, the authors show a rise in positive affect, which is associated with a decrease of uncertainty and emotion regulation. They identify a partisan divide in moral and emotional reactions that emerged after the first US death.
DBLP:conf/icwsm/GuoBRL22.paperResultsText: These results show how collective emotional states have changed since the pandemic began, and how social media can provide a useful tool to understand, and even regulate, diverse patterns underlying human affect.
